p.s: The article Language learning in the UK: can't, won't, don't published in The Telegraph on 27th January 2015 written by John Worne, deals with the growing issue of foreign language learning in the UK and its possible consequences for the future in many sectors.
First of all there is to say that John Worne sums up the national view on speaking foreign languages, what also includes his own opinion: that students do not speak or learn enough foreign languages.
The author examines a decreasing number of students in the UK who decide to study foreign languages at university level.
This fact represents Worne's shocked view abuot the engagement todaystoday's UK students showsshow us with these numbers.
After that he states that language learning comes up more in primary schools at the same time, but in GCSE and A-level the usage of languages dodoes not grow anymore.
In addition to that John Worne explains how important it is for the UK to learn foreign languages in many different sectors.
The author points out that technologies, like translators, will save the future businesses and sees especially there a problem why students do not learn foreign languages that much more.

Additionally he likes the idea of some universities which give students opportunity to study a foreign language beside another degree subject and appeals that more young people should take this chance.
Furthermore Worne stresses his view that the UK students have to improve on their language.
In the end he adds that also parents could help to change something in school and education system to spur on young people learning foreign languages.
He sees a relevant role in parents for a successful improvement and change.

To sum up there is to say that John Worne points out many significant facts regarding foreign language learning in the UK and personally states that there havehas to be a change in schools and education system to encourage young people to improve on their language skills due to the relevance in our increasingincreasingly globalized world.
He sees a big importance in an urgent development.
